author: By Clifford Krauss
title: As Western Oil Giants Cut Production, State-Owned Companies Step Up
description: In the Middle East, Africa and Latin America, government-owned energy companies are increasing oil and natural gas production as U.S. and European companies pare supply because of climate concerns.
content: HOUSTON — After years of pumping more oil and gas, Western energy giants like BP, Royal Dutch Shell, Exxon Mobil and Chevron are slowing down production as they switch to renewable energy or cut costs after being bruised by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Voelk
title: With Car Lots Sparse, Shoppers Drive Home in Their Second Choice, or Third …
description: Amid a shortage of new cars, many buyers have been forced to kick the tires of overlooked models and brands.
content: The most desirable new vehicles are selling before they even hit dealerships. Used-car prices are through the sunroof. And automakers worldwide are idling plants and cutting capacity as they wait for more desperately needed chips to be delivered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Adam Schiff on Facebook, Fox News and the Trump Cult
description: The congressman gives an update on the Jan. 6 committee and talks about the future of Trump and the country.
content: Since this interview was taped, the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot has issued an additional subpoena, bringing the number of subpoenas to 19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: Smutty Smiff Gets His Bass Back
description: A rare instrument was discovered in a pawnshop after being missing for 40 years. The internet reunited it with its owner in a matter of days.
content: The bass is back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Mississippi Threatens to Sue Brett Favre Over $828,000
description: The former Green Bay Packers quarterback was among more than 10 people who received letters from the state auditor demanding repayment of tens of millions of dollars connected to an extensive welfare fraud scheme.
content: Mississippi, the state that reveres the Hall of Fame quarterback Brett Favre as a homegrown hero, threatened this week to sue him if he does not repay $828,000 that he owes within 30 days, according to the state auditor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: An N.B.A. Female ‘First’ Hopes It’s Not Such a Big Deal Soon
description: Lisa Byington, the league’s first full-time female play-by-play broadcaster, with the Milwaukee Bucks, said she’s proud but hopes the novelty has a short shelf life.
content: MILWAUKEE — It had the feel of the first day of school for Lisa Byington, who was learning her way around Fiserv Forum, where the Bucks play their home games. A couple of television production trucks were stationed in a corridor not far from the court, but Byington faced a dilemma: Which belonged to Bally Sports Wisconsin, the team’s broadcast partner?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Jon Gruden’s Emails: What We’ve Learned So Far
description: Here’s what we know about the emails from the former Las Vegas Raiders coach, and what happened after they came to light.
content: Jon Gruden resigned as the coach of the N.F.L.’s Las Vegas Raiders this week after The New York Times reported that he had made racist, homophobic and misogynistic remarks in numerous emails over the past 12 years. The emails were disclosed as part of an investigation into workplace misconduct on the Washington Football Team, an inquiry that did not directly involve Gruden.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Books Led a Young Jane Goodall to Live Among the Chimps
description: “There was no TV when I was a child. I learned from books — and nature. I read every book about animals I could find. Doctor Dolittle and Tarzan led me to dream about living with animals in Africa.”
content: “There was no TV when I was a child,” says the primatologist Jane Goodall, author (most recently) of “The Book of Hope.” “I learned from books — and nature. I read every book about animals I could find. Doctor Dolittle and Tarzan led me to dream about living with animals in Africa.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles V. Bagli
title: Robert Durst Sentenced to Life in Prison for Friend’s Murder
description: A jury found that Mr. Durst, subject of the HBO series “The Jinx,” killed a longtime friend in 2000 because of what she knew about his wife’s disappearance nearly 40 years ago.
content: Nearly four decades after his wife’s abrupt disappearance cast a cloud of suspicion that would make his case one of the most notorious in the country, Robert A. Durst was sentenced on Thursday to life in prison for the execution-style killing in 2000 of a close confidante.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Hard Luck Love Song’ Review: A Glossy Take on a Gritty Tune
description: Drawn from the plotline of a Todd Snider song, the film follows a pool shark and an escort, taking twists that are both violent and silly.
content: Movies based on popular songs often bring specifics to the table to better capitalize on the hooks. For Bobbie Gentry’s “Ode to Billy Joe,” the 1976 movie adaptation took on a question the song doesn’t answer: Just what did Billy Joe and the narrator throw off the Tallahatchie Bridge? On the other hand, all the 1954 movie “White Christmas” required was its title Irving Berlin song, some more Irving Berlin songs and stars in Santa hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dr. Eric Cassell, Bioethicist Who Put the Patient First, Dies at 93
description: A professor and prolific author, he cautioned that doctors too often focus on the disease instead of the overall well-being of the sufferer.
content: Dr. Eric Cassell, a distinguished medical ethicist who urged fellow doctors to shift priorities beyond curing their patients’ diseases to caring for their overall well-being, died on Sept. 24 at his home in East Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Halloween Kills’ Review: There Will Be (Copious Amounts of) Blood
description: The newest installment of the “Halloween” franchise, starring Jamie Lee Curtis, is a murderous mess that substitutes corpses for characters.
content: After a dozen movies — and a 13th on the horizon — the once-monstrous Michael Myers shuffles into theaters this weekend as exhausted as the 43-year-old franchise that indulges his blood lust. “Halloween Kills,” the middle film of a reboot trilogy started in 2018 by the director David Gordon Green, is an indolent, narratively impoverished mess that substitutes corpses for characters and slogans for dialogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Video Game Limits, Parental Involvement in Dating and Road Trips
description: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
content: Welcome to our roundup of student comments on our recent writing prompts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Greek Reds Have Yet to Have Their Moment. Is Now the Time?
description: An importer wondered why Italian wines have caught on more easily. One reason is simply familiarity. Greek reds can be superb but they are unknown.
content: I recently met with a Greek wine importer, who, in addition to introducing me to a few excellent bottles, detailed his 20 years of frustration at trying to persuade a reluctant American public to take a chance on Greek wines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lesley Evans Ogden
title: How Hungry Sea Otters Affect the Sex Lives of Sea Grass
description: A habit that appeared damaging at first glance seems to make oceanic ecosystems more resilient, scientists found.
content: Jane Watson studied sea otters for decades, but it was in the 1990s that the ecologist in British Columbia observed they had a destructive habit. While conservationists were working diligently to restore damaged sea grass meadows elsewhere in the world’s oceans, it seemed ironic that in northern Vancouver Island’s sea grass habitat, which is much healthier than others in the world, the furry floaters would swoop in and dig for clams, dislodging the aquatic vegetation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Conductor’s Impossible Legacy
description: The sublime artistry of Wilhelm Furtwängler collided with his role as de facto chief conductor of the Nazi regime.
content: We live in a time of intense scrutiny of the moral failings of artists — even, or perhaps especially, those whose creations we admire. And in few classical musicians is the gap between sublime work and shameful actions greater than the conductor Wilhelm Furtwängler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: Cowboys’ Trevon Diggs Is Among the N.F.L.’s Breakout Stars
description: Diggs, with his league-leading six interceptions, and emergent talents like Atlanta’s Cordarrelle Patterson and Arizona’s Rondale Moore have surprised opponents.
content: Cornerbacks typically endure miserable rookie seasons: The receivers they cover are bigger, faster and craftier than the ones they faced in college, while quarterbacks are quick to exploit their every blunder. But Trevon Diggs’s rookie season with the Dallas Cowboys was especially dreadful. The University of Alabama standout and second-round draft pick allowed easy touchdowns, whiffed on multiple tackles and often looked as though he wasn’t certain of his assignments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The Trip’ Review: With This Gun, I Thee Shoot
description: In this Norwegian thriller on Netflix, a murderous couple get more bloodshed than they bargained for.
content: Most people don’t prepare for getaways with their spouses by buying a hammer, a hacksaw, duct tape and rope — but Lars (Aksel Hennie) is not most people, and “The Trip,” directed by Tommy Wirkola, is not most movies. Its initial premise is this: Lars has planned to murder his wife, Lisa (Noomi Rapace), during their holiday, but he’s thwarted when it turns out Lisa has been preparing to do away with him on the very same trip. Unfortunately, while that concept promises a fun, agile thriller, “The Trip” all too quickly descends into a juvenile, nihilistic mess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Russ Kick, ‘Rogue Transparency Activist,’ Is Dead at 52
description: Working on his own, he used the Freedom of Information Act to publish suppressed documents, sometimes making front-page news.
content: On the eve of the American-led invasion of Iraq in March 2003, the Pentagon banned media coverage of the return of the remains of dead soldiers to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In Katie Couric’s ‘Going There,’ There Includes Family Skeletons, Busting Into the Boys’ Club and More
description: The “Today” host and “CBS Evening News” anchor shares her story, from her suburban childhood to her trailblazing media career.
content: Early in her broadcasting career, Katie Couric tried using her given name, Katherine, onscreen: “to counteract my Campbell’s Soup Kid looks,” she writes in a new book that has been leaking like unburped Tupperware throughout the media ecosystem. To “lend an air of authority my face and voice lacked.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Almost Famous: The Unchosen One’
description: He was nearly selected to be in “Star Wars.” But then his dreams were shattered. What are the perils of being a child actor?
content: “Almost Famous: The Unchosen One” is a 16-minute film that touches on themes of childhood, fame and disappointment. It profiles Devon Michael who was a rising child actor in the 1990s until he auditioned for the role of the young Anakin Skywalker in “Star Wars.” Reflecting on the experience many years later — the pressure, the criticisms, the dashed hopes — Mr. Michael urges the public not to forget that child actors are just kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Katie Benner
title: Jan. 6 Panel Moves to Recommend Criminal Charges Against Bannon
description: The House select committee investigating the Capitol riot will vote next week to recommend a criminal contempt of Congress charge against Stephen K. Bannon after he defied a subpoena.
content: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House inquiry into the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol said the committee would move next week to recommend that Stephen K. Bannon, a former top adviser to President Donald J. Trump, face criminal contempt charges for refusing to cooperate with its investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Teenager Sentenced to 9 Years to Life in Killing of Tessa Majors
description: Luchiano Lewis admitted to taking part in the 2019 attack in which Ms. Majors, an 18-year-old Barnard College student, was stabbed to death in Morningside Park.
content: A teenager who last month pleaded guilty to murder in the killing of an 18-year-old Barnard student was sentenced on Thursday to nine years to life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Must I Be Kind to My Money-Grubbing Parents?
description: A reader who inherited the family business feels conflicted about continuing to support its former owners.
content: I am the third-generation owner of a family business. The company is struggling now, and I can no longer afford to pay my parents who stopped working 11 years ago but still draw paychecks. Though the company has no legal obligation to pay them, my dad is threatening litigation. I made them an offer that will be burdensome for me to pay, but I’ll do it if it keeps the peace. My dilemma: When people come into the business and ask about my parents — or say: “What great people!” — how should I respond, considering they have put me in financial and emotional peril?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: What’s Behind the Energy Crunch in Britain and Europe
description: Natural gas prices have skyrocketed, pressuring manufacturers and households with high energy bills.
content: Just as economies seemed to be returning to something like normal, an energy crunch has hit Britain, the rest of Europe and much of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Traveling Alone, in Groups
description: Group tour companies are accommodating more and more solo travelers, who are looking for company — and someone else to handle the complexities of traveling during the pandemic.
content: After Sheila Katz’s husband died of a degenerative nervous system disorder in April, she knew she had to get away. But her husband had been her travel partner, and without him, she was hesitant to travel alone. The pandemic’s ever-shifting travel regulations were intimidating as well. So Ms. Katz, 45, did something she’d never done before: She joined a group tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: For In-Person School, Fulfilling Students’ Wish Lists
description: After remote learning, these New Yorkers received assistance buying supplies and new clothes as they headed back to the classroom.
content: Catherine Fils’s three children were all starting at new schools. And this year, she was determined to continue their annual tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: The big banks are bullish about the recovery.
description: Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase have all reported quarterly profits that beat analysts’ expectations.
content: Experts are warning that U.S. economic growth may be easing. But as far as the country’s biggest banks are concerned, the recovery is going just fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A blow for populism in Europe.
content: This past weekend, Andrej Babis, the Czech Republic’s seemingly invincible populist leader, was the unexpected loser of its elections, after a coalition of previously divided center-right parties united against him. They had a simple, clear message: We can beat Babis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico City Replaces a Statue of Columbus With One of an Indigenous Woman
description: The replacement of a figure seen as a monument to colonialism touched a nerve as the country debates how it is shaped by race and sex.
content: MEXICO CITY — Statues of Columbus are being toppled across the Americas, amid fierce debates over the region’s legacy of European conquest and colonialism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Ray Fosse, 74, Catcher Best Known for a Collision, Is Dead
description: He was a budding Cleveland talent when he was knocked over by Pete Rose in the 1970 All-Star Game. It was, he said, “something people will continue to talk about.”
content: Ray Fosse, the strong-armed catcher whose career was upended when he was bowled over by Pete Rose at the 1970 All-Star Game, died on Wednesday. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Texas, Harbinger of Doom
description: Mississippi was one of the states at the vanguard of the first Jim Crow; Texas may well be at the vanguard of the next.
content: When Jim Crow was originally established, it spread from state to state like a contagion, each subsequent state taking lessons from the ones before it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: How Homeowners’ Associations Get Their Way in California
description: The lasting power of neighborhood organizing.
content: In the last edition of my newsletter, I wrote about Los Angeles City Councilwoman Nithya Raman and the challenges she’s faced in her political career. Raman ran on a host of progressive policy prescriptions, but her housing plans — construction of more affordable units and homeless services — were what brought her into a face-off with powerful political forces that threaten to remove from her district most, if not all, of her constituents. This newsletter is about what those forces are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Renews Its Support for Trade Group It Once Made a Punching Bag
description: Trade Representative Katherine Tai outlined her vision for the battered World Trade Organization, saying the U.S. wanted to re-engage and address working people’s concerns.
content: Katherine Tai, the United States trade representative, affirmed the Biden administration’s commitment to supporting the World Trade Organization in a speech in Geneva on Thursday but said further reforms were needed to restore the global trade body’s relevance to working people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘The Velvet Underground’ Review: And Me, I’m in a Rock ’n’ Roll Band
description: Todd Haynes’s documentary paints a jagged, revelatory portrait of the New York avant-garde scene of the 1960s.
content: Sometime in the 1960s, John Cale, a classically trained Welsh violist with avant-garde leanings, met Lou Reed, a middle-class Jewish college dropout from Long Island who dreamed of being a rock star. Their creative partnership, encouraged by Andy Warhol and enhanced by the mercurial presence of the German model, actress and singer Nico, was the volatile bedrock of the Velvet Underground, a commercially marginal band that altered the course of popular music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: A New Wellness Brand That Harnesses the Power of the Garden
description: During the pandemic, longtime creative director Scott Formby found respite, and inspiration for a new venture, in his own lushly planted backyard.
content: Even when the creative director Scott Formby was working around the clock for fashion and interior brands like Ralph Lauren and Frette, he’d figure out a way to get himself outdoors. “I’d organize a shoot in the middle of a garden on the Amalfi Coast,” he recalled recently from his home in Los Angeles’s Hollywood Hills. When he bought this 1920s Spanish Colonial-style house 15 years ago, its 2,500-square-foot terraced garden, on a connected but separate lot, was a large part of the appeal, and after the drought that hit the area in 2014, he transformed it to reduce its water requirements. “I kept the old lemon trees but added a lot of cactuses and, inspired by the Mediterranean, fig and mandarin trees,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Dunham
title: Lena Dunham on Joy Sorman and Unnameable Female Pain
description: “Life Sciences” follows the youngest in a family of women plagued by mysterious, unheeded illnesses.
content: LIFE SCIENCES By Joy Sorman Translated by Lara Vergnaud
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: LeBron James’s SpringHill sells a minority stake to a group led by RedBird.
description: The deal values the entertainment, apparel and marketing company, which Mr. James founded with Maverick Carter last year, at about $725 million.
content: LeBron James and his longtime business partner Maverick Carter want to become major players in the film, television, gaming, consumer products, audio and live-events businesses (among others). On Thursday, four investors — RedBird Capital, Fenway Sports Group, Nike and Epic Games — agreed to “pour gasoline” on those ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘All About My Sisters’ Review: Family Matters
description: Wang Qiong’s debut feature traces the tragic effects of China’s one-child policy on her family.
content: Often in “All About My Sisters,” the Chinese filmmaker Wang Qiong’s documentary portrait of her family, you might forget that what you’re watching is filtered through a camera. Over a period of seven years, Wang filmed her parents, siblings and relatives from within the emotional thicket of their lives, capturing moments of piercing, private intimacy. Her approach yields a film bristling with the kind of familial rancor that usually only emerges behind closed doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Ducker
title: Remi Wolf Turns Bedroom Pop Into Hypercolored Explosions
description: The 25-year-old Los Angeles musician’s debut album, “Juno,” is a collage of sounds, emotions and cultural detritus filtered through her own unique energy.
content: LOS ANGELES — Remi Wolf rolled up to an indoor trampoline park in Van Nuys on an August afternoon feeling frazzled. She’d been busy all day, making bugged-out visuals for her songs and prepping for tour. Then the traffic coming from the Eastside of Los Angeles was bad. So, so bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump to Testify in Lawsuit Over Bodyguards’ 2015 Clash With Protesters
description: The former president had long avoided being questioned in the case, and it is not clear whether his testimony will become public.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump is expected to testify on Monday at Trump Tower as part of a lawsuit brought by a group of activists who said that they were violently attacked by his bodyguards in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: F.B.I. Official Fired Under Trump Wins Back His Pension
description: Andrew G. McCabe, the former F.B.I. deputy director, will receive his pension and other benefits after settling his lawsuit with the Justice Department.
content: WASHINGTON — Hours before he was scheduled to retire in 2018, Andrew G. McCabe, then the F.B.I.’s deputy director, was fired by the Justice Department, depriving him of his pension and prompting cheers from President Donald J. Trump, who had been hounding him over his role in the Russia investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: U.S. Charges Once-Rising Artist With Selling Raymond Pettibon Forgeries
description: Christian Rosa is accused in a federal indictment of scheming to defraud art buyers through the sale of four pieces purportedly by Mr. Pettibon.
content: In a message posted on the artist Raymond Pettibon’s Twitter account two years ago, he appeared to express his gratitude to two friends who had paid him a visit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Vjosa Isai
title: Meteorite Crashes Through Ceiling and Lands on Woman’s Bed
description: After a fireball streaked through the Canadian sky, Ruth Hamilton, of British Columbia, found a 2.8-pound rock the size of a large man’s fist near her pillow.
content: Ruth Hamilton was fast asleep in her home in British Columbia when she awoke to the sound of her dog barking, followed by “an explosion.” She jumped up and turned on the light, only to see a hole in the ceiling. Her clock said 11:35 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: ‘Disability Drives Innovation’
description: Audiobooks are an example of a technology developed by or for people with disabilities that has helped all of us.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nigel Cliff
title: A History of Modernity That Puts Africa at Center Stage
description: “Born in Blackness,” by the former New York Times correspondent Howard W. French, is a deeply researched account of the continent’s often overlooked role in the development of the modern world.
content: BORN IN BLACKNESS Africa, Africans, and the Making of the Modern World, 1471 to the Second World WarBy Howard W. French
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: In Pennsylvania Governor’s Race, Josh Shapiro Focuses on Voting Rights
description: Mr. Shapiro, the state’s attorney general and a Democratic candidate for governor, has been on the forefront of legal efforts to defend the 2020 election.
content: Thirty seconds into his official campaign for governor in Pennsylvania, Josh Shapiro wanted to talk about voting rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily Burana
title: My Mental Health Issues Have a Name: Bruce
description: And like Mr. Springsteen, I have resolved to release the shame.
content: I’m probably not going to make the strongest case for my mental soundness by telling you that Bruce Springsteen lives inside my brain. But here we are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea will donate 1.6 million vaccine doses to Vietnam and Thailand.
description: South Korea plans to ship almost 1.6 million doses of AstraZeneca’s coronavirus vaccine to Vietnam and Thailand this week, the foreign ministry announced Tuesday, as the Southeast Asian nations struggle to contain the spread of the virus.
content: South Korea plans to ship almost 1.6 million doses of AstraZeneca’s coronavirus vaccine to Vietnam and Thailand this week, the foreign ministry announced Tuesday, as the Southeast Asian nations struggle to contain the spread of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Border With Canada to Open, and North Country ‘Could Not Be Happier’
description: Businesses along New York State’s northern border were celebrating the news that fully vaccinated Canadians would soon be allowed into the United States again.
content: Fall has traditionally been a fat time for businesses in New York’s North Country, as Canadian visitors flood into the region to celebrate holidays like Canadian Thanksgiving, taking in dazzling displays of foliage and feasting on big sales at local retailers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Raymond Gniewek, 89, Met Orchestra’s Enduring Concertmaster, Dies
description: For 43 years he was a steadying force with the ensemble as he helped it become one of the world’s most esteemed.
content: Raymond Gniewek, the concertmaster for the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra for 43 years and a quiet but vital force in elevating that ensemble to a new level of renown, died on Oct. 1 in Naples, Fla. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Kannapell
title: Here’s what happens next after an F.D.A. panel considers more Covid booster shots.
description: Further steps will be required at the F.D.A. and at the C.D.C., in a process that ends with the states.
content: An independent panel of experts advising the Food and Drug Administration voted on Thursday to recommend a booster shot for many recipients of the Moderna coronavirus vaccine, and will meet on Friday to consider booster shots for recipients of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: The early decades of Disney animation were filled with female faces: Snow White, Alice in Wonderland, Sleeping Beauty and more. But the women who helped create those characters and the movies that featured them have often gone as unrecognized as Cinderella at the prince’s ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Kaag
title: Why Does Thoreau Live On? A Few Famous Writers Offer Answers.
description: In “Now Comes Good Sailing,” an anthology gathered by Andrew Blauner, famous writers including Pico Iyer, Lauren Groff and Amor Towles meditate on Thoreau’s influence.
content: NOW COMES GOOD SAILINGWriters Reflect on Henry David ThoreauEdited by Andrew Blauner
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: These Worms Left the Ocean Floor and Never Looked Back
description: By evolving lighter bodies and oar-like appendages, these “creepy crawlies” of the sea floor are able to take to the water and wriggle up toward the surface.
content: The average scale worm trudges along the seafloor like a tiny armored tank. The worm’s overlapping scales shield its backside from predators, while bristled appendages help it scuttle through the mud. This is a good life for a worm, said Katrine Worsaae, a marine zoologist at the University of Copenhagen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 20, 2021
description: How worried should American consumers be about inflation (rising prices)?
content: These seven graphs are from a group of 179 consumer product and services graphs, which appeared in The New York Times, that show the inflation (increase, in red) or deflation (decrease, in blue) of year-over-year (“change from 12 months prior”) prices. For example, television’s November 2020 dark blue arrow icon represents an approximate 20 percent decrease in average price over November 2019 average price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Johnson
title: How Students and Teachers Benefit From Students Annotating Their Own Writing
description: Three ways to integrate annotation into the writing process that are inspired by our Annotated by the Author series.
content: A couple of years ago, we began a new series called Annotated by the Author, part of our Mentor Texts collection, in which we invite New York Times journalists, and winners of our student contests, to annotate their work, revealing the writing choices they made and explaining why they made them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Moderna, Steve Bannon, ‘Succession’: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should We Eliminate Gifted and Talented Programs?
description: New York City announced that it will phase out these programs in an effort to desegregate its public schools. Is this the right thing to do?
content: Have you ever attended a school or program where students were grouped by ability levels? If yes, do you think it was beneficial to your learning and education? How so?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Texas Judge Urges New Trial for Death Row Inmate, Citing Jurist’s Antisemitic Remarks
description: A judge’s recommendation paves the way for an appeals court to decide whether Randy Halprin, a Jewish man who was convicted and sentenced to death in 2003 for his role in the killing of a police officer, will get a new trial.
content: A Texas judge strongly recommended this week that a convicted murderer on death row be granted a new trial because of the blatant racism and antisemitism that she said the trial judge had displayed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Luzzu’ Review: Capturing Culture on the Coasts of Malta
description: This subtle drama follows a young Maltese fisherman torn between fidelity to his trade and the demands of a modern world.
content: In the naturalistic drama “Luzzu,” Jesmark (Jesmark Scicluna) spends days bobbing and fishing in bright sea waters off the coast of Malta. Though fish are few and money is tight, Jesmark treasures his trade and the cheerfully painted luzzu — or quaint wooden fishing boat — that has been passed down through his paternal lineage for generations. But once he and his wife Denise (Michela Farrugia) learn that their infant son requires pricey medical care, Jesmark must negotiate between his fidelity to fishing and the demands of a modern world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Alex Murdaugh Charged With Swindling Sons of Dead Housekeeper
description: Mr. Murdaugh, the scion of a legal dynasty in South Carolina, is accused of pocketing about $2.8 million in settlement money that was supposed to go to the housekeeper’s family.
content: Alex Murdaugh, the South Carolina lawyer who has endured a dramatic downfall since his wife and son were shot in an unsolved killing in June, was arrested on Thursday and charged with swindling millions of dollars from the sons of his former housekeeper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: U.S. Regains Seat at U.N. Human Rights Council, 3 Years After Quitting
description: The Trump administration called the 47-nation council hypocritical and said it was vilifying Israel. The Biden administration says the U.S. can be more effective as a member.
content: The United States on Thursday regained a seat on the United Nations Human Rights Council, which the Trump administration abandoned in 2018 because of what it called the body’s hypocrisy and anti-Israel prejudice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Everything Is Getting More Expensive
description: Persistently high inflation is a problem for the Fed and the White House.
content: Consumer prices rose more than economists expected last month, new numbers show, on top of an already high August reading. While a jump in prices was expected as the economy recovered from the pandemic shock, persistently high inflation is complicating plans for both the Fed and the White House, who face pressure to act so that price gains don’t become a permanent fixture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judge John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Childhood Allergies
description: Is a husband’s memory of pineapple-induced rashes a real health concern or a dad-joke mind game?
content: Suzanne writes: My husband says that children’s cough syrup made him hyperactive, and pineapple gave him a rash. I recently went with him to the E.R., and when he brought this up, I actually saw the doctor roll his eyes. I say he sounds ridiculous. He vehemently disagrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: The S&P 500 snaps out of its funk with its best day in months after good earnings and economic reports.
description: The benchmark U.S. index rose 1.7 percent following a broad-based surge in share prices of materials, tech and health care companies.
content: Robust bank earnings, softer inflation data and a solid update on the job market drove stocks to their best day in months on Thursday, as the market moved decisively higher after weeks of sideways waffling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Berates Fox News for Its Reporting on Vaccine Mandate
description: Meyers took Tucker Carlson to task for not “being certain” while reporting falsehoods.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Walgreens’ coronavirus vaccinations exceed expectations, bolstering sales.
description: The drugstore chain’s parent company said that it delivered 13.5 million vaccinations in the three months that ended in September.
content: Walgreens Boots Alliance administered coronavirus vaccinations at a higher-than-expected rate, delivering 13.5 million vaccinations in the three months that ended in September, which helped bolster its sales, the company reported on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Introducing, Selma Blair’ Review: An Actress in Her Second Act
description: A window into the actress’s battle with multiple sclerosis.
content: The documentary “Introducing, Selma Blair” presents a bracingly relatable version of an often all-too-artificial event: a performer navigating the process of reinvention. Change came to the actress Selma Blair involuntarily, when she was diagnosed with the autoimmune disorder multiple sclerosis, a disease that attacks the central nervous system, in August 2018. She went public with her illness with an Instagram post in October of that year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: The Brooklyn Nets’ Kyrie Irving defends his decision not to get vaccinated.
description: The N.B.A. star, who is set to make $40 million this year, said he opposes vaccine mandates, saying nobody should be “forced” to do it.
content: Kyrie Irving, the N.B.A. star who has been indefinitely barred from practicing or playing with the Brooklyn Nets because of his refusal to get the Covid-19 vaccine, spoke out publicly on Wednesday night for the first time since the team decided to keep him off the court, saying his refusal was a matter of personal freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Six out of seven coronavirus cases in Africa are going undetected, the W.H.O. says.
description: “Now is the time to go on the offensive against Covid-19, and work with local communities to break transmission chains and stop wider outbreaks from happening,” Dr. Matshidiso Moeti said.
content: Official statistics on coronavirus cases in Africa give the impression that the continent has avoided the worst of the pandemic. But in a continent where most deaths are not formally registered and many countries are struggling to vaccinate their people, the great majority of coronavirus cases — an estimated six out of seven — are going undetected, according to Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, the Africa director at the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Newly Discovered Bat Viruses Give Hints to Covid’s Origins
description: Coronaviruses discovered in Laotian bats are surprisingly adept at infecting human cells, showing that such deadly features can indeed evolve outside of a lab.
content: In the summer of 2020, half a year into the coronavirus pandemic, scientists traveled into the forests of northern Laos to catch bats that might harbor close cousins of the pathogen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Bill Cosby Is Sued by Woman Who Says He Sexually Assaulted Her in 1990
description: The suit was filed under a change in New Jersey law that extended the deadline to sue in cases involving allegations of sexual assault.
content: A woman sued Bill Cosby in New Jersey on Thursday, accusing the entertainer of drugging and sexually assaulting her at a hotel in Atlantic City in 1990, when she was 26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: With Boone’s Status Unclear, Yankees Begin Coaching Changes
description: Two hitting coaches and the third-base coach will not return after the team’s early playoff exit. Manager Aaron Boone’s contract expires after the season.
content: After a seesaw season that ended with a disappointing one-game playoff loss, the 92-win Yankees are overhauling their coaching staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: John Deere Workers Strike in Contract Dispute
description: About 10,000 unionized employees walked out, as worker activism rises during nationwide labor shortages.
content: Some 10,000 unionized workers at the agriculture equipment maker Deere & Company went on strike early Thursday after overwhelmingly rejecting a contract proposal worked out with the company by negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden Considering Robert Califf, a Former F.D.A. Commissioner, to Lead Agency Again
description: The F.D.A. has been without a permanent chief since President Biden took office.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House is considering nominating Dr. Robert M. Califf, a former Food and Drug Administration commissioner, to once again lead the agency, according to five people familiar with the search for a candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Narrowing the vaccine race gap.
content: Black Americans were once less likely than any other racial group to be vaccinated. But a wave of pro-vaccine campaigns, employer mandates and a surge of virus deaths have helped narrowed that gap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden calls on businesses to ‘step up’ as he expresses optimism about the fight against the virus.
description: “I’m calling on more business to step up. I’m calling on more parents to get their children vaccinated when they are eligible,” President Biden said.
content: President Biden pleaded with Americans to remain vigilant against the coronavirus on Thursday, rallying states and private businesses to support vaccine mandates in an effort to avoid a surge in cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Promotes Vaccine Donation in Meeting With Kenya’s President
description: The two leaders were also expected to discuss the escalating humanitarian crisis in the Tigray region of Ethiopia, where fighters have been accused of atrocities against civilians.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday announced the donation of millions of coronavirus vaccines to a group of African countries during a meeting with President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, which is contending with the pandemic and an unfolding humanitarian disaster in neighboring Ethiopia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Carlos Correa Is OK With Being the Heel
description: The Houston Astros shortstop is a vocal leader on the field and happy to be the team’s spokesman off it, even when it comes to discussing the team’s scandalous past.
content: HOUSTON — It was a small moment, and it was perhaps unnoticed by many watching Game 4 of the American League division series claimed by the disdained Houston Astros over the Chicago White Sox on Tuesday. But it captured exactly what Astros shortstop Carlos Correa has meant to his team.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Tarot-like tableware, a young photographer’s first book — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: ‘Lurching Between Crisis and Complacency’: Was This Our Last Covid Surge?
description: Rising immunity and modest changes in behavior may explain why cases are declining, but much remains unknown, scientists say.
content: After a brutal summer surge, driven by the highly contagious Delta variant, the coronavirus is again in retreat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: At Rallies, Trump Fans Wear Their Grievances
description: For some, it’s not enough to go to an event in the name of Donald J. Trump — their attendance also requires wearing something that embraces some of his political calling cards.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: YouTube’s stronger election misinformation policies had a spillover effect on Twitter and Facebook, researchers say.
description: The prevalence of videos claiming fraud dropped sharply, according to New York University’s Center for Social Media and Politics.
content: YouTube’s stricter policies against election misinformation was followed by sharp drops in the prevalence of false and misleading videos on Facebook and Twitter, according to new research released on Thursday, underscoring the video service’s power across social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Rising Off the Mat, U.S. Rallies Past Costa Rica
description: Sergiño Dest scored one goal and set up another as the United States regained its stride with a dominant performance in World Cup qualifying.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — A spectator at a United States men’s soccer game could have a reasonably enjoyable time simply watching Sergiño Dest as he goes about the business of playing right back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Marc Santora
title: Deadly Clashes in Beirut Escalate Fears Over Lebanon’s Dysfunction
description: The fighting further traumatized the small Mediterranean country, a patchwork of sects that has tumbled into an abyss of devastating political and economic crises.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Armed clashes between sectarian militias transformed Beirut neighborhoods into a deadly war zone on Thursday, raising fears that violence could fill the void left by the near-collapse of the Lebanese state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Enough With the Seltzer: The Booze-Free Cocktail Has Arrived
description: In the last five years, at least five new dry stores that sell alcohol-free wines, craft beers and bottled drinks have opened in New York City.
content: Killian Moore, a building superintendent, stopped drinking six years ago. This meant a lot of seltzer at parties. It grew tiresome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Wheel of Fortune and Fantasy’ Review: What We Talk About
description: In three stories, men and women circle one another as they casually and cruelly share intimacies, express desires and voice doubts.
content: The geometry of desire is elegantly plotted in “Wheel of Fortune and Fantasy,” a wistful, moving, outwardly unassuming movie. In three segments, men and women circle one another, talking and talking some more. As they exchange glances, confessions and accusations, their cascading words become either bridges or walls. Throughout these effusive roundelays, they yearn — for meaning, former lovers, lost intimacy, an escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Deaths from tuberculosis rose in 2020, for the first time in a decade, the W.H.O. says.
description: The trend confirmed warnings that the coronavirus pandemic would undermine progress against other infectious diseases around the world.
content: Deaths from tuberculosis, the world’s biggest infectious disease killer until the Covid-19 pandemic arrived, have increased for the first time in more than a decade, totaling more than 1.5 million people in 2020. That trend is expected to worsen in 2021 and 2022, according to a report released on Thursday by the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: With Whiskers and Wit, the NY Cat and Dog Film Festivals Return
description: After a pandemic-induced hiatus, these celebrations of human-animal bonds are screening in Manhattan and beyond.
content: Two annual cinematic celebrations invariably attract impassioned ticket buyers, even though they lack car chases, explosions, alien invasions or Daniel Craig as a pouty James Bond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Former Boeing Pilot Is Indicted in 737 Max Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors say Mark Forkner deceived the F.A.A. and was “scheming to defraud” customers.
content: A federal grand jury on Thursday indicted a former top pilot for Boeing, Mark Forkner, in connection with statements he and the company made about its troubled 737 Max jet, the culmination of a long investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Bergman Island’ Review: Love Among the Cinephiles
description: In Mia Hansen-Love’s new film, Vicky Krieps and Tim Roth play filmmakers on the rocks in the Baltic Sea.
content: “This is your landscape, Bergman. It corresponds to your innermost imaginings of forms, proportions, colors, horizons, sounds, silences, lights and reflections.” That is Ingmar Bergman, in his memoir “The Magic Lantern,” rhapsodizing on his “secret love,” the island of Faro in the Baltic Sea. Starting in 1960 with “Through a Glass Darkly,” he shot many of his films on Faro and died there in 2007.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Frida Kahlo, Aztec Gods: Can Art Lift Up a Poor Neighborhood?
description: A new cableway and hundreds of giant murals have brightened lives in Iztapalapa, Mexico City’s most populous neighborhood, but poverty and attacks against women are still pervasive.
content: MEXICO CITY — Observed from a soaring cable car, the city is a sea of concrete stretching to the horizon, ruptured only by clusters of skyscrapers and the remains of ancient volcanoes. Some 60 feet below is the borough of Iztapalapa, a warren of winding streets and alleyways, its cinder block houses encasing the neighborhood’s hills in insipid gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Texas Removed an L.G.B.T.Q. Resource Page After a Candidate Complained
description: Don Huffines, who is challenging Gov. Greg Abbott in next year’s Republican primary, said the content on the state web page was “offensive.” It was quickly removed.
content: The State of Texas removed a web page that offered resources to gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender youth after one of Gov. Greg Abbott’s Republican primary challengers said its content was “offensive” and out of line with “Texas values.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Texas Man Is Sentenced for Using Dating App to Target Gay Men
description: The man, Daniel Jenkins, was part of a group that used the app Grindr to lure gay men to an apartment complex in Dallas to rob and assault them, prosecutors said.
content: A Texas man was sentenced to 23 years in federal prison on Wednesday for his connection in a scheme that used the popular dating app Grindr to target gay men for violent hate crimes, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Sticky Stuff
description: Ashton Anderson churns out eight debut answers that might be surprising in their simplicity.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle is lucky No. 13 for Ashton Anderson, who gravitates to Friday and Saturday submissions, whether he is working solo or collaborating with another constructor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Was Suddenly Sick and Shaking Violently. What Was Going On?
description: Was it a tick-borne parasite — or something weirder?
content: The 41-year-old man eased his car into a spot in front of a chain drugstore at the northern edge of Albuquerque. He felt awful. Suddenly he began to shiver, then shake. He watched helplessly as his arms, his legs, his entire 6-foot-5-inch body jumped and jolted like a rag doll shaken by a child. When the shivering stopped, the air-conditioned car suddenly felt as hot as the desert air outside. Nausea swept over him, and he opened the door just in time to vomit the little he’d been able to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: The Most Important Global Meeting You’ve Probably Never Heard Of Is Now
description: Countries are gathering in an effort to stop a biodiversity collapse that scientists say could equal climate change as an existential crisis.
content: As 20,000 government leaders, journalists, activists and celebrities from around the world prepare to descend on Glasgow for a crucial climate summit starting late this month, another high-level international environmental meeting got started this week. The problem it seeks to tackle: A rapid collapse of species and systems that collectively sustain life on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: “The American experiment” is a slippery little phrase, summoning the country’s noblest ideals while leaving generous room to forgive our failures to achieve them. But the term endures precisely because it is so imprecise — it’s broad enough to apply to a wide range of the titles on this week’s list, for instance, whether they concern the gritty details of forming a centralized constitutional government (in new histories by the venerable Joseph J. Ellis and Gordon S. Wood) or the hopes of a high school basketball team during an epidemic of suicides on a Native American reservation (in “Brothers on Three,” by Abe Streep). Fiona Hill’s memoir of an up-from-the-bootstraps British immigrant who becomes an expert analyst on the National Security Council, only to testify in the impeachment trial of an American president? That’s part of the experiment. So is Andrea Elliott’s “Invisible Child,” her minutely observed profile of a New York schoolgirl struggling against the scourge of homelessness. And so in its way is the story of Peter Thiel, the tech billionaire and prolific supporter of right-wing causes, whose dislike of small-d democracy is weirdly evocative of arguments going back to the country’s founding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Plan Another Bid to Break G.O.P. Voting Rights Filibuster
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the top Democrat, announced he would force another vote next week to bring legislation to the floor despite a Republican blockade.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats will try again next week to advance a voting rights measure, Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, announced on Thursday, though Republicans are expected to maintain their filibuster against the legislation backed by all Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Beirut protests turn violent.
content: At least six people were killed and dozens were injured during clashes between militias that briefly turned Beirut neighborhoods into a war zone on Thursday. Here are the latest updates.

author: By Alex Marshall
title: British Museums Face Covid’s Long-Term Effects
description: Months of closures during the pandemic have caused financial havoc for art venues, and many expect to be strapped for years. At the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, the virus’s impact is clear.
content: LONDON — The Victoria & Albert Museum in London has one of Britain’s most eccentric collections of treasures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Roasted Squash Is the Start of Something Beautiful
description: Turn it into cozy rice porridge or a warm lentil salad, or dress it up with an all-purpose savory topping.
content: One of my favorite ways to dress a vegetable goes like this: Fry some mustard seeds and curry leaves, toss some ground coconut, crushed garlic and dried red chiles into the pan, and let it all toast very lightly. That’s it. This crumbly, sweet and savory topping is quick to make and goes with almost any vegetable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Can Lab-Grown Burgers Help Stop Climate Change?
description: Lab-grown meat has been hailed as a solution to humanity's unsustainable consumption of animal products, but some say the idea is a fantasy.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: A Loyal Catholic’s Mission to Protect the Church From Youth Football
description: Denny Doyle is concerned about the risk of brain injuries to children who play tackle football. And he worries that his beloved church will also pay a price.
content: CINCINNATI — Denny Doyle is a committed Catholic and a lifelong football fan, and he saw little conflict between the two until his grandson was old enough to play the game. That’s when he began reading about the risks that tackle football posed to young boys, whose brains are particularly vulnerable to concussions. To Doyle’s relief, his grandson opted for flag football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The School That Aspires to Be a Basketball Factory (Not That Kind)’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a high school that uses basketball as a way to learn and prepare for a range of career opportunities. Then, they will design their own dream high school.
content: Featured Article: “The School That Aspires to Be a Basketball Factory (Not That Kind)” by David Waldstein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Beauford Delaney: Portraits Glowing With Inner Light
description: In “Be Your Wonderful Self” at Michael Rosenfeld Gallery, abstraction and portraiture achieve a remarkable unity.
content: The art of the American painter Beauford Delaney, who died over four decades ago, deserves sustained attention from a major New York museum. That it has not already happened is breathtaking. In a moment when the histories of art, and especially Black American art, are expanding in all directions, Delaney seems to be hiding in plain sight. His work is one of the signal achievements of 20th-century American art. New York, his home for 24 years, is where most of his development took place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diane Seuss and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: [I hope when it happens]
description: Diane Seuss’s work is a reminder of how a good line stays with you like some love.
content: There is a poem by Diane Seuss that begins, “Jesus wept and so did Rowena Lee,” and what follows is the kind of buildup of living and suffering and what happens as it all goes down that reminds me of how a good line stays with you like some love. This poem from Seuss’s new collection is like that, all the remembering that makes you grateful for the kisses you remember. Or, as my good friend asks me when I need asking, “Dwayne, how is your heart?” Which, I swear, is a way to say I love you. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

content: The hundreds of new laws that Gov. Gavin Newsom has signed over the past several weeks include plenty of “firsts.”

content: He tried and failed to buy The Baltimore Sun. Now the Maryland hotel magnate Stewart W. Bainum Jr. is creating an ambitious publication meant to compete with it.

title: ‘Needle in a Timestack’ Review: Put a Pin in It
description: The director John Ridley, who wrote “12 Years a Slave,” tries to combine time travel and romance, and comes up short twice.
content: Who among us has never dreamed of turning back time and changing a decision or event, just like Cher and the Terminator? That possibility is a reality in John Ridley’s sluggish, blandly slick time-travel romance, “Needle in a Timestack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea’s Mightiest Weapons? Nukes and Shirtless Men on Broken Glass.
description: The country has never been known for its subtlety, and martial-art stunts have long been a mainstay of its propaganda, designed to stoke national pride and instill fear in enemies.
content: SEOUL — A soldier rams his head through a stack of hard tiles. Another stands unfazed as others smash his arm, thigh and head with wooden bars. A​ shirtless commando lies on broken glass with a thick slab of granite on his belly that is smashed with a hammer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: On London Stages, Brevity Reigns Supreme
description: A new work by Caryl Churchill, the final installment in Hilary Mantel’s Cromwell saga and a Larry Kramer play deploy their running times with varied success.
content: LONDON — Theatrical convention has never mattered to Caryl Churchill, the questing English playwright who at 83 continues to display a maverick intelligence. “What If If Only,” her new play for her longtime home, the Royal Court, runs only 20 minutes — which is six minutes longer than was widely reported when the three-performer drama was first announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Two 100-Win Teams. Winner-Take-All Game. Play Ball.
description: For the fifth time in baseball history, teams with 100 or more victories will face off in a do-or-die postseason game. For the Dodgers and the Giants, a rivalry complicates matters.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Leo Durocher had lived enough baseball to know what the moment demanded: Sportsmanship, the personal acknowledgment of a job done well by a rival. Jackie Robinson had shown him the way.

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Van Gogh Watercolor, Once Seized by Nazis, to be Sold at Auction
description: Christie’s estimates the work could fetch as much as $30 million, and is being sold under the terms of an agreement between the current owner and the heirs of Jewish collectors who once owned it.
content: A watercolor by Vincent van Gogh, seized by the Nazis during World War II and not publicly exhibited since 1905, is to be sold at auction next month in New York, where experts at Christie’s estimate it could sell for between $20 and $30 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Fatally Shoots Woman at Girlfriend’s Home, Police Say
description: The officer, whom a police official identified as Yvonne Wu, also shot and wounded her girlfriend, the police said.
content: A New York City police officer was in custody late Wednesday after admitting to fatally shooting a woman whom she encountered in her girlfriend’s Brooklyn apartment and shooting the girlfriend as well, officials said.

title: Netflix Loses Its Glow as Critics Target Chappelle Special

content: It was looking like a great year for Netflix. It surpassed 200 million subscribers, won 44 Emmys and gave the world “Squid Game,” a South Korean series that became a sensation.

title: U.S. Holds Global Meeting to Fight Ransomware, Minus the World’s No. 1 Culprit
description: Russia, the biggest source of the problem, was not invited to the 30-nation conference, which sought to engage allies in efforts to disrupt cybercrime.
content: WASHINGTON — When the White House convened 30 nations this week to formulate strategies for combating ransomware, one country was intentionally omitted: Russia, the single biggest source of the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Fall for Dance Review: Splats, Blue Moods and Go-Go Grooves
description: This mixed-nuts dance series returned with a whiplash-inducing program of Streb Extreme Action, A.I.M by Kyle Abraham and the Verdon Fosse Legacy.
content: The happy crowd attending the opening night of New York City Center’s Fall for Dance festival on Wednesday snaked around the block. The cause of the bottleneck was the inspection of vaccination records at the door — one of very few differences between this incarnation of the popular event and the many that came before the pandemic.

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: U.S. Open Stars Fall at Indian Wells, Which Struggles to Draw a Crowd
description: The tournament, the first major sporting event canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic in March 2020, was moved to October for its return, but attendance is down by half and atmosphere is lacking.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — With no teenagers and no Daniil Medvedev left in the draw, this tournament will definitely not be a repeat of the U.S. Open.

title: Frost Bit

content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There are a lot of misconceptions about The New York Times — better known to some by the sobriquet “The Gray Lady” — and chief among them is that anything even remotely salacious is unceremoniously quashed by a team of white-shoed editors in an ivory tower.

title: An Alaska lawmaker barred from flying over masking rules has Covid.
description: The Republican state senator, Lora Reinbold, drew widespread attention after video surfaced of her confrontation with Alaska Airlines employees over mask policies.
content: An Alaska lawmaker who was barred from Alaska Airlines flights after she defied a federal mandate requiring passengers to wear masks disclosed this week that she had tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Murphy
title: Britain Infected Volunteers With Covid. Why Won’t the U.S.?
description: The controversial history of human challenge trials.
content: In an age of masking, compulsive hand sanitizing and plexiglass dividers, it seems inconceivable that for more than 40 years people enthusiastically signed up — and were often put on a waiting list — to have respiratory viruses, including coronaviruses, dripped into their noses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: The Secret to Better Running? Try Distraction
description: Focusing on external sights and sounds, rather than what’s going on in your body, made running feel easier and improved performance.
content: To make running seem easier, try paying attention to anything other than your body. That’s according to a fascinating new study of the ways in which how we focus as we move can affect how we feel as we move. The study was small and involved novice female runners, but the findings suggest that the more closely runners listen to their bodies, the more draining their running can become, both physically and psychologically. Conversely, the more runners distract themselves from what their bodies are doing as they put one foot in front of the other, the more effortless their run may feel, and the better their performance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s the expert panel considering Moderna and J.& J. booster shots.

content: A committee of scientific advisers to the Food and Drug Administration is meeting on Thursday and Friday to examine the available data on using additional doses of the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines to boost immunity.

title: Nicholas Kristof Leaves New York Times as He Considers a Political Run

content: After 37 years at The New York Times as a reporter, a high-level editor and an opinion columnist, Nicholas Kristof is leaving the newspaper as he considers running for governor of Oregon, a top Times editor said in a note to the staff on Thursday.

title: LinkedIn to Shut Down Service in China, Citing ‘Challenging’ Environment
description: The Microsoft-owned service had censored posts in China, in compliance with the country’s laws, to operate there.
content: SEATTLE — LinkedIn said on Thursday that it was shutting down its professional networking service in China later this year, citing “a significantly more challenging operating environment and greater compliance requirements,” in a move that completes the fracture between American social networks and China.

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Held for Ransom’ Review: Negotiating With Terrorists
description: This thoughtful hostage drama from Denmark depicts the events surrounding the capturing of Daniel Rye, a photojournalist, by ISIS in 2013.
content: Like most films about contending with Islamic terrorists, there’s an ickiness to entertainment value derived from pitting white Westerners against big bad Muslims. Should you be willing to overlook certain intrinsic difficulties, “Held for Ransom” is a surprisingly thoughtful hostage drama given the blunt meatheadedness of its title.

author: By Jason Farago
title: Getting a Grip on Unreality
description: These 10 standout artists — from Colombia to Egypt to Japan — redrew the map of Surrealism, the 20th century’s most provocative art movement. They and dozens more are reunited at the Metropolitan Museum.
content: In dreams you can go anywhere; in dreams no place is too far. “Surrealism Beyond Borders,” a round-the-world tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a map of another globe: a planet redrawn by artist-mapmakers, where old geographic assumptions no longer make sense. Melting watches, men in bowler hats? You can keep them. In this show the classics of Surrealism — that lobster telephone! — cede the center stage to desires and nightmares from Haiti and Puerto Rico, Japan and Korea, Egypt and Mozambique. In these distorted reflections we see Surrealism as an all-pervasive approach to artistic freedom, where Europe has no monopoly on your desires.
source.name: The New York Times

content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — It was known among locals as the city’s “No. 1 ghost building” — a once-prosperous property that began to deteriorate badly after a fire two decades ago. Squatters and gamblers moved in. Piles of debris blocked stairwells.

title: No, Australia Is Not Actually an Evil Dictatorship

content: SYDNEY, Australia — Ron DeSantis, the Republican governor of Florida who has made a name for himself as an extreme opponent of vaccine mandates, announced at the end of last month that Australia was “not a free country.” This was surprising news — most of all to Australians.

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Noroît’ Review: In a French Vision, Pirates Inhabit a Jacobean Drama
description: When this unusual film, made in 1976 by the French director Jacques Rivette, opens in New York this week, it will be making its official debut here.
content: After his masterworks of the early 1970s, “Out 1” and “Celine and Julie Go Boating,” the French filmmaker Jacques Rivette conceived one of his typically ambitious projects: a four-film cycle called “Scenes From a Parallel Life.” Like “Celine and Julie,” and so many Rivette films to follow, these pictures would center on female characters and offer alternate realities by (among other things) playing with genres ancient and modern. Two of the planned four were completed in 1976, both of which are being revived this week.
